audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker introducing himself and stating his intention to give a short presentation. He mentions the project was inspired by things Henning talked about and focuses on fixing implementation problems with CNN models in the healthcare sector, particularly in predicting pneumonia from X-ray images. He highlights problems with using this approach, including the "black box problem" and legal barriers. The speaker's tone is informational and engaging. The clip concludes with the speaker interjecting with "God."

The audio begins with a male speaker introducing an idea that moves beyond simply visualizing what a CNN model is doing. He describes a desire to make it possible for a doctor or radiologist to discuss "with the AI on the individual level." The speaker describes a back and forth where the medical professional can ask questions and voice their own assessments, aiming to build a better working relationship with the AI. The goal is for this interaction to occur in the same framework familiar to the doctor, without requiring computer science expertise. The speaker concludes by summarizing the intent of this approach. The speaker sounds enthusiastic and articulate, with a confident tone.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing a prototype and what it can generate from an image, mentioning they will go into detail later. He then refers to two pictures and explains that they come from giving a model an X-ray image. He mentions it's their own trained model, based on CNN architecture. The model predicts pneumonia with 99% probability.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the use of something called a "gradcam," defining it as a tool used when talking about the convolutional neural network, asking the AI which parts of a picture or features were most important for a decision, which results in a "red blob." He explains that this is difficult to interpret, essentially saying that it highlights certain pixels as more important, without explaining what that means. He continues discussing a process called "Automatic Zone Division of Grad Cams". The speaker has a calm and instructional tone.

The clip features a male speaker with a clear and enthusiastic tone, explaining a process involving "Grad-CAM" and dividing an area into "zones" colored based on red pixels. He uses the example of a radiologist looking at an X-ray, then relays how AI might analyze the same area. The speaker concludes with the radiologist then comparing these analyses and agreeing or disagreeing on a case-by-case basis. The overall goal is the possible collaboration between a human and artificial intelligence.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker discussing how to automatically make a box plot, mentioning examples like "right long," "right long mid," "left long," and emphasizing that it provides the "exact number of things." He then pauses and continues speaking.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that the content is "all generated." He clarifies that any X-ray image can be input and the result will "pop out." He then provides further examples of other X-ray images being used. The tone is informative and somewhat technical.

A male speaker with an informative tone explains the functioning of CNNs, noting "if you're wondering how we make this" and mentioning "the first layer." He describes it as "the first eyes this computer has" and explains the convolutional layer, indicating it says "that's a cycle" before further details.

A male speaker is describing the function of a convolutional layer for lung images, explaining how it outlines the lung and helps identify sections for analysis. He outlines the theory of the AI model being used to estimate the probability of pneumonia in X-rays and identify zones of importance. His tone is informative and enthusiastic.

The clip begins with a man speaking about a "GUI" and program intended to be "friendly to use" and then confirms "yes". He continues, saying "So yeah, you can see" describing how to input an x-ray image and that it will "make that". Following the speech, there is a short sound effect that seems to indicate success or completion of a task.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing their research project. He touches on how they made two models just for testing, and how one can technically "take any model you have, and use this framework with it." The speaker then states in theory it could work to make it "easier to build trust and have a better working relationship as a doctor with your AI." A different male voice asks about a cooperation with Ph.D. students. The primary speaker responds and there is background chatter.

The clip starts with a male speaker mentioning working with a PhD student named Danna, who gave them an image of the relationship between radiologists and the development of AI. According to the speaker, Danna pointed them to the idea that people are ready to trust these things but the legal limitations are the problem, so they thought of a solution. The male speaker sounds professional and informative.

The audio features a single male speaker, who expresses gratitude towards someone, mentioning their helpful insights into the field, admitting his lack of knowledge in radiology before this, stating he's studying to be a data scientist. The speaker's tone is conversational. The audio ends abruptly.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker offering to answer "any questions, if I have time." The speaker maintains a relatively neutral tone. This is followed by a sound that suggests a round of applause, presumably in response to the speaker.
